b'RT @devisridhar: @BillGates @gavi @WHO @CDCgov So tough question: where do you think SARS-CoV-2 came from? What data do you want to see? An\xe2\x80\xa6'

b'@devisridhar @gavi @WHO @CDCgov I am optimistic about polio eradication - we are close. Malaria, HIV, Nutrition, will take a lot longer but better tools are coming. Education also needs innovation - it is behind where global health is particularly for girls.#'

b'@devisridhar @gavi @WHO @CDCgov From 2000 to the start of the pandemic we made strong progress on health and other goals. The pandemic is a huge setback - including rich countries not focusing on the needs of developing countries as much. I hope we can reverse that.'
b"RT @devisridhar: @BillGates @gavi @WHO @CDCgov I'd make a joke but would cause a storm\xf0\x9f\x98\x86. Turning to the Gates Foundation's mission, what do\xe2\x80\xa6"

b"@devisridhar @gavi @WHO @CDCgov People like you and I and Tony Fauci have been subject to a lot of misinformation. I didn't expect that. Some of it like me putting chips in arms doesn't make sense to me - why would I want to do that?#"

b'@devisridhar @gavi Trusted authorities like @WHO  and @CDCgov need more resources to see the pandemic early (surveillance) and to communicate better. Social media got behind on trying to get factual information out - there will be a lot of debate about how to do better on that...'
b'RT @devisridhar: @BillGates @gavi One major problem has been online misinformation on Facebook & other platforms around vaccines, masks and\xe2\x80\xa6'

b'@devisridhar @gavi Do you think the world will come together to get ready for the next one? I hope so but I am not sure.#'
b"@devisridhar @gavi Also some countries did a better job of reducing mobility, using masks and protecting the elderly.\n\nWe weren't prepared - no practice in advance.#"

b'@devisridhar @gavi A few countries like Australia moved fast to diagnose cases at scale and isolate people who were infected. They were able to limit deaths dramatically. Once the numbers get large in a country it is too late. So the first few months made a lot of difference.'
b'RT @devisridhar: @BillGates @gavi Looking back on 2020/21 (and given you warned of a respiratory pandemic for years before), what do you th\xe2\x80\xa6'
b"RT @devisridhar: @BillGates There's been a lot of discussion on responsibility of pharma companies like Pfizer/Moderna for access. What is\xe2\x80\xa6"
b'RT @devisridhar: @BillGates Agree 100%- next gen vaccines with sterilising immunity. 2nd question: What are the current challenges in reach\xe2\x80\xa6'

b'@devisridhar When we have adequate supply then tiered pricing is used where the rich countries pay a lot more than middle income and low income pay the least which is funded by @gavi. When supply is limited rich countries have to not outbid the others so governments are key to this. #'
b"@devisridhar mRna vaccines still can't meet all the demand so figuring out who gets what is complicated.#"

b'@devisridhar During 2021 the supply of vaccines was limited and they mostly went to wealthy countries. Now we have a lot of supply overall and the problems are logistics and demand. The health systems in developing countries are a limiting factor.'

b'@devisridhar The vaccines we have prevent severe disease and death very well but they are missing two key things.

First they still allow infections ("breakthrough") and the duration appears to be limited.

We need vaccines that prevent re-infection and have many years of duration.#'

b'The world has lost a hero. Archbishop Desmond Tutu led with his values, empathy and optimism. He put everyone he met at ease with his incredible laugh and energy. He inspired me with his sense of purpose to build peace out of the struggle of oppression. I will miss him greatly.'
b'One of my favorite holiday traditions is sharing books with family and friends. Here are 5 books I loved reading this year: https://t.co/lhvffVsmgC'

b'Mamello Makhele is a hero from Lesotho who traveled by foot and donkey to bring health services to women in need during the pandemic. Her story is nothing short of inspiring: https://t.co/UyI4x0VxhK https://t.co/3MLP5nvm5l'

b'I know it\xe2\x80\x99s frustrating to go into another holiday season with COVID looming over us. But it won\xe2\x80\x99t be like this forever. Someday the pandemic will end, and the better we look after each other, the sooner that time will come.'

b'If there\xe2\x80\x99s good news here, it\xe2\x80\x99s that omicron moves so quickly that once it becomes dominant in a country, the wave there should last less than 3 months. Those few months could be bad, but I still believe if we take the right steps, the pandemic can be over in 2022.'

b'There will be more breakthrough cases in people who are vx\xe2\x80\x99d, which sounds concerning but is purely a factor of how many people are vx\xe2\x80\x99d and how fast this variant is spreading. Vaccines are designed to prevent people from getting seriously ill or dying & are doing that well.'

b'In the meantime, we all have to look out for each other, especially the most vulnerable, whether they live down the street or in another country. That means wearing masks, avoiding big indoor gatherings, and getting vaccinated. Getting a booster gives the best protection.'

b'The big unknown is how sick omicron makes you. We need to take it seriously until we know more about it. Even if it\xe2\x80\x99s only half as severe as delta, it will be the worst surge we have seen so far because it\xe2\x80\x99s so infectious.'
b'Omicron is spreading faster than any virus in history. It will soon be in every country in the world.'

b'Just when it seemed like life would return to normal, we could be entering the worst part of the pandemic. Omicron will hit home for all of us. Close friends of mine now have it, and I\xe2\x80\x99ve canceled most of my holiday plans.'

b'If we make the right decisions now\xe2\x80\x94informed by science, data and the experience of medical professionals\xe2\x80\x94we can save lives and get the country back to work. You can read more about my thoughts on #COVID19 on my blog. https://t.co/KN58B8Hs11'

b'In the meantime, frontline health care workers are making heroic efforts to test and treat patients across the United States and the world. Here in my hometown, Public Health Seattle & King County (@KCPubHealth) is doing incredible work that we should all be very proud of.'

b'All the work that rich countries are doing now to develop vaccines will save lives in developing countries too. Without a vaccine, those countries are at even greater risk than wealthy ones, because it\xe2\x80\x99s even harder for them to do physical distancing and shutdowns.'

b'If everything goes well, there might be an effective vaccine in less than 18 months\xe2\x80\x94the fastest a vaccine has ever been developed. That will depend on decisions we make today, including the federal government investing in building up manufacturing capacity.'
b'Work is going full speed on potential treatments, and vaccines. But people should know that it will take time to prove they are safe and effective and to start making them.'

b'There\xe2\x80\x99s been some progress on more efficient testing methods, such as the self-swab developed by the Seattle Coronavirus Assessment Network. I hope this and other innovations in testing are scaled up across the country soon. https://t.co/qdrr7Qz16r'

b'The federal government needs to step up on testing: far more tests should be made available, and we should aggregate the results so we can quickly identify potential volunteers for clinical trials and know with confidence when it\xe2\x80\x99s time to return to normal.'

b'Extreme physical distancing measures will make a big difference in the U.S., but we need a consistent nationwide approach. Until the case numbers start to go down across America\xe2\x80\x94which could take 10 weeks or more\xe2\x80\x94no one can continue business as usual or relax the shutdown.'

b'The portion of the global economy that doesn\xe2\x80\x99t fit the old model just keeps getting larger. But the rules that govern the economy haven\xe2\x80\x99t kept up. This is one of the biggest trends in the global economy that isn\xe2\x80\x99t getting enough attention.'

b'Unlike the goods that powered our economy in the past, software is an intangible asset -- \xe2\x80\x9csomething you can\xe2\x80\x99t touch.\xe2\x80\x9d And it\xe2\x80\x99s not the only example: data, insurance, e-books, even movies work in similar ways.'
b'But software doesn\xe2\x80\x99t work like this. Microsoft might spend a lot of money to develop the first unit of a new program, but every unit after that is virtually free to produce.'
b'This chart assumes that the total cost of production increases as supply increases. When a car company makes a new vehicle, the 10th car costs the same to manufacture as the 1000th.'
b'At the time I was in college, this was basically how the global economy worked... https://t.co/2polaSbsXY'

b'.@melindagates @WarrenBuffett @sapinker 14/ This is an amazing time to be alive. I hope you make the most of it.'
b'.@melindagates @WarrenBuffett @sapinker 13/ This is the core of my worldview. It sustains me in tough times and is the reason I love my work. I think it can do same for you.'
b'.@melindagates @WarrenBuffett @sapinker 12/ It doesn\xe2\x80\x99t mean you ignore the serious problems we face. It just means you believe they can be solved.'
b'.@melindagates @WarrenBuffett @sapinker 11/ That matters because if you think the world is getting better, you want to spread the progress to more people and places.'
b'.@melindagates @WarrenBuffett 10/ @SAPinker shows how the world is getting better. Sounds crazy, but it\xe2\x80\x99s true. This is the most peaceful time in human history.'
b".@melindagates @WarrenBuffett 9/ If I could give each of you a graduation present, it would be this--the most inspiring book I've ever read. https://t.co/P67BuvpELJ"
b'.@melindagates 8/ Like @WarrenBuffett I measure my happiness by whether people close to me are happy and love me, & by the difference I make for others.'
b'7/ Meanwhile, surround yourself with people who challenge you, teach you, and push you to be your best self. As @MelindaGates does for me.'
b'6/ You know more than I did when I was your age. You can start fighting inequity, whether down the street or around the world, sooner.'
b'5/ I also have one big regret: When I left school, I knew little about the world\xe2\x80\x99s worst inequities. Took me decades to learn.'
b'4/ E.g. Intelligence takes many different forms. It is not one-dimensional. And not as important as I used to think.'
b'3/ Looking back on when I left college, there are some things I wish I had known.'
b"2/ AI, energy, and biosciences are promising fields where you can make a huge impact. It's what I would do if starting out today."
